para.sentence: This differential equation has a regular singularity at \rho=0 with indices \ell+1 and -\ell , and an irregular singularity of rank 1 at \rho=\infty (§§2.7(i), 2.7(ii)).
There are two turning points, that is, points at which \ifrac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}\rho}^{2}}=0 (§2.8(i)).
The outer one is given by \rho_{\mathrm{tp}}\left(\eta,\ell\right)=\eta+(\eta^{2}+\ell(\ell+1))^{1/2}.

The function F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right) is recessive (§2.7(iii)) at \rho=0 , and is defined by F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right)=C_{\ell}\left(\eta\right)2^{-\ell-1}(\mp\mathrm {i})^{\ell+1}M_{\pm\mathrm{i}\eta,\ell+\frac{1}{2}}\left(\pm 2\mathrm{i}\rho \right), or equivalently F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right)=C_{\ell}\left(\eta\right)\rho^{\ell+1}e^{\mp \mathrm{i}\rho}M\left(\ell+1\mp\mathrm{i}\eta,2\ell+2,\pm 2\mathrm{i}\rho \right), where M_{\kappa,\mu}\left(z\right) and M\left(a,b,z\right) are defined in §§13.14(i) and 13.2(i), and C_{\ell}\left(\eta\right)=\frac{2^{\ell}e^{-\pi\eta/2}|\Gamma\left(\ell+1+ \mathrm{i}\eta\right)|}{(2\ell+1)!}.
The choice of ambiguous signs in (33.2.3) and (33.2.4) is immaterial, provided that either all upper signs are taken, or all lower signs are taken.
This is a consequence of Kummer’s transformation (§13.2(vii)).
F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right) is a real and analytic function of \rho on the open interval 0<\rho<\infty , and also an analytic function of \eta when -\infty<\eta<\infty.

The normalizing constant C_{\ell}\left(\eta\right) is always positive, and has the alternative form C_{\ell}\left(\eta\right)=\dfrac{2^{\ell}\left((2\pi\eta/(e^{2\pi\eta}-1)) \prod_{k=1}^{\ell}(\eta^{2}+k^{2})\right)^{\ifrac{1}{2}}}{(2\ell+1)!}.

The functions {H^{\pm}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right) are defined by {H^{\pm}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right)=(\mp\mathrm{i})^{\ell}e^{(\pi\eta/2)\pm \mathrm{i}{\sigma_{\ell}}\left(\eta\right)}W_{\mp\mathrm{i}\eta,\ell+\frac{1}{ 2}}\left(\mp 2\mathrm{i}\rho\right), or equivalently {H^{\pm}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right)=e^{\pm\mathrm{i}{\theta_{\ell}}\left( \eta,\rho\right)}(\mp 2\mathrm{i}\rho)^{\ell+1\pm\mathrm{i}\eta}U\left(\ell+1 \pm\mathrm{i}\eta,2\ell+2,\mp 2\mathrm{i}\rho\right), where W_{\kappa,\mu}\left(z\right) , U\left(a,b,z\right) are defined in §§13.14(i) and 13.2(i),

{\theta_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right)=\rho-\eta\ln\left(2\rho\right)-\tfrac{1} {2}\ell\pi+{\sigma_{\ell}}\left(\eta\right), and {\sigma_{\ell}}\left(\eta\right)=\operatorname{ph}\Gamma\left(\ell+1+\mathrm{i }\eta\right), the branch of the phase in (33.2.10) being zero when \eta=0 and continuous elsewhere.

{H^{+}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right) and {H^{-}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right) are complex conjugates, and their real and imaginary parts are given by {H^{+}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right)=G_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right)+\mathrm{i} F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right),{H^{-}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right)=G_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right)-\mathrm{i} F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right).
As in the case of F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right) , the solutions {H^{\pm}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right) and G_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right) are analytic functions of \rho when 0<\rho<\infty.
Also, e^{\mp\mathrm{i}{\sigma_{\ell}}\left(\eta\right)}{H^{\pm}_{\ell}}\left(\eta, \rho\right) are analytic functions of \eta when -\infty<\eta<\infty.
